p: Changing environmental conditions and associated spatial and temporal variability in krill biomass differentially affected whale numbers depending on their feeding distribution across latitudes and oceanic regions (Figure S2). Predicted declines in krill and copepod biomass in latitudes 50–60°S resulted in declining numbers of southern right, humpback and fin whales that feed predominantly in the mid‐latitudes. In contrast, increases in krill biomass around Antarctica in the highest latitudes (70–80°S, Figure 2f) resulted in concomitant increases in numbers of ice‐associated blue and minke whales in the Atlantic/Indian region (Figure 3a,e).
